conclusion: To determine if the displacements of cars A and B are the same from t=0 to t=t1, we need to analyze their velocity-time graphs.
The displacement of an object is given by the area under its velocity-time graph over a specified time interval.
Car A starts with a velocity of v1 and ends with a velocity of v2 at time t1.
Car B starts with a velocity of v2 and ends with a velocity of v1 at time t1.
The displacement for each car is the area under its respective velocity-time graph from t=0 to t=t1.
The graph for Car A is a straight line from (0, v1) to (t1, v2).
The area under the graph for Car A is a trapezoid with bases v1 and v2 and height t1.
The area (displacement) for Car A is calculated using the formula for the area of a trapezoid: Area_A = 1/2 * (v1 + v2) * t1.
The graph for Car B is a straight line from (0, v2) to (t1, v1).
The area under the graph for Car B is also a trapezoid with bases v2 and v1 and height t1.
The area (displacement) for Car B is calculated using the same formula for the area of a trapezoid: Area_B = 1/2 * (v2 + v1) * t1.
Both displacements are calculated using the same formula: Area_A = Area_B = 1/2 * (v1 + v2) * t1.
Since the expressions for the areas are identical, the displacements of Car A and Car B are the same.
Yes, the displacements of cars A and B are the same from t=0 to t=t1.
